title: Will Open Source AI Overtake Closed Models? Ft. Olama, Fireworks and Open Router

rawLines.text: So now we're welcoming Sonia Hang for
our next panel on open source with Dimma
from Fireworks. We got Alex At It Atala
from Openrooder and of course Captain
Jeffrey Morgan from Olama to talk about
the other side of the equation, the open
source future that you all can use and
plug into your products and adopt today.
Please welcome them to the stage.
Thank you. Uh, Alex, Dimma, Jeff, thank
you so much for joining us. We heard
Jensen speak this morning with an
impassioned plea for the importance of a
thriving open-source model ecosystem.
And I think everyone in this room is
fully aligned behind that vision. So,
I'm delighted that we have this panel
today. Uh, let's do a first quick first
round of intros. Um, maybe say your name
and then what your company does in a
sentence or two. Hi, I'm Jeff. Thanks
for having me. Um uh I'm a founder of
Olama. It's the easiest way to get up
and running with uh open-source
LLMs and uh that's me. Yeah. Hi, I am
Dimma. I'm co-founder of Fireworks and
you heard from uh my co-ounder Lynn this
morning also in the presentation. And
yeah, Fireworks is as you heard in the
morning is a best place to build and
scale this generative AI. So we help you
to fine-tune and serve models at really
fast and large scale and obviously we
are very big proponents of open source
models because that's that's what we're
doing this and yeah I'm passing to Alex
we are happy to be one of the providers
on open router
too. I'm Alexa CEO and co-founder of
open router. We're a language model
router and marketplace. Uh a way to just
have one service that gives you the best
pricing, performance, and uptime for
models. And we work closely with uh a
lot of different providers, but in a
very big way with fireworks that to make
that happen. Great. Okay. Let's start
with the problem statement that Jensen
framed for us this morning. Some of the
fear-mongerers in the ecosystem are
pushing to have open source models
heavily regulated or banned. Um
obviously the people in this panel
probably don't agree with that. Um you
guys are the champions of the open
source ecosystem. Like what would you
say? How would you make the case for uh
the importance of open source?
I um you know I think like a fundamental
principle behind open source is that
human genius can still come from
anywhere around the world and that uh
centralizing it behind model labs is
very risky and it's not it's not a it's
not as good of a bet it's not as high
leverage of a bet as allowing genius to
come from anywhere and what I think like
language models and and uh generative of
AI unlocks is for the ability for
somebody with uh access to unique
intelligence that can't be found
anywhere else to create a a a service
that generates it uh on demand when
anyone wants and we're just going to I
think we're in a period right now where
open source is not winning there it's uh
compared to closed source it's about 20
to 30% of our inference in terms of
tokens used uh but um and and it's also
like a lastmile optim optimization for a
lot of companies or like you have one
customer that just like refuses to work
with some closed source model provider
and you want to serve them anyway. Um,
but I think like the fact that it's
transparent and the fact that uh it's
very very high leverage compared to
closed source models means that when
like the young kids of today grow up
like really thinking about uh
state-of-the-art machine learning on the
edge, they're just going to make
something open source before they make
something closed source because they
won't be able to work at a model lab.
Um, and then we'll start seeing really
wild things develop. If I can add, I
mean it's a question of practicality. So
on two fronts, one is um a lot of the
open source models are deployed on
non-data center hardware and so it ends
up the customer has access to it
anyways. For a consumer there's a
question, well if you're going to
distribute the model on their device,
how hard is it for them to realistically
access it. Um kind of like you know
maybe Photoshop in the old days or how
operating systems are increasingly um
free for consumers. Um, and often these
models aren't fully open in the sense of
the data and the training and the paper,
but the weights are there. And so if
you're downloading the model anyways,
you're kind of getting the weights on
the enterprise front. Um, when a lot of
these enterprises are really excited
about customizing the model and if you
know these things are banned, um, but
enterprises still want this. There's
probably a way that that could still
work. Um, but then you'd be asking,
well, the the customer wouldn't, you
know, really own the entire result. And
from what we've learned, that's really
important for customers that when they
fine-tune or train or distill a model
with their own data that they own the
entire model, not some, you know, I
don't know, piece of it. Uh, and so
those are two kind of practical
questions that I think we'd have to work
through if that is the case.
And to add to that, uh, I mean,
basically, if you view AI as like
general purpose technology, right, even
from global kind of benefiting the
society, like you can try to regulate
electricity or something, right? like
you can try to regulate applications and
like distribution how the market work
but like you shouldn't ban the basic
technology and I feel from that
perspective it's just from like
developing of scientific progress it's
useful and uh yeah to the point of
customization we also see like a lot of
people like wanting to customize and
tune and like actually build AI first
products and that's where like the same
argument for like open source software
like you want if it's a core part of
your product you want to customize it
you want to control it you want to be
basically in actually on that note show
of hands who here uses open models in
their in their production stacks today.
Okay, good amount of the crowd. Um,
Alex, I want to pull on the thread that
you mentioned earlier, which is that the
open source models are or the open
models are behind right now. Say more
about that dynamic and how do you think
that'll play out?
So right now I I mean I see most of the
large model labs trying to build more
more general powerful foundation models
that you need to fine-tune less and that
work for more use cases. Um, I kind of
if I were to make a prediction now, I'd
think that fine-tunes are maybe going to
have a weak moment in the next year or
so as these powerful RL models scale up
and f like the the marginal benefit you
get from fine-tuning gets outweighed by
the obsolescence risk from doing so. But
um we're just still at the very
beginning, as everybody today has said,
of a massive wave of adoption where just
most businesses still haven't even tried
anything. And when that wave is further
along, um I I expect a very similar
thing to happen that happened with
software where people just want
transparency and they want
customizability. And then we might see
like I don't know if it'll be called
fine-tuning in that future, but we may
see some like it has to be open source
type customization arrive that uh that
only the that the open source community
will land on probably first. And who do
you think will be the stalwart of that
kind of frontier foundation model uh
providing? In the past it was it was
meta for a long time with llama. Before
that I remember mistrol was big. So,
one, I'm curious what h what you think
happened to Mistrol. Uh, right now it
seems like DeepSeek is is all the rage.
Um, but who do you think will be kind of
the research labeconomic engine tied to
it that will be driving a lot of the
kind of frontier development on the open
side?
Question for any of you. I think it's
kind of hard to predict because there
are a lot of factors involved. Like the
magic of open source is that you
basically need like at least one player
at any given time to release a good
model, right? Uh, to build upon. So I
think you know the leader might change
in this the space but like the over
overall kind of marketing industry will
continue. I think what's common with

from Meta is each of those companies is
seeking to solve a problem that's not
just distributing the model and selling
it. Um you may have seen Meta's app they
launched this week which is a social
network effectively. Um and um from
spending some time with the model
builders in China, they are also looking
to solve the next great consumer app or
consumer use case. And so on the way to
that, they're kind of just open sourcing
these models. And so you know, I think
with DeepSeek, what we happen to see was
they happen to along that path to that
because they have no reason to keep
these things closed source. They get
more feedback if they open source it um
that they can open source along the way
and they end up open sourcing something
great. I think it was pretty difficult
to predict the deepseek moment that
happened in January. Let's talk more
about the deepseek moment. How how did
this happen? And you know we have Zuck
throwing lots of compute at Llama. Um
how did we get to the point where you
know a Chinese model uh was was top of
the top of the leaderboards but also
more importantly top of developers minds
in the open source world?
Well, I mean I think like from model
itself like they did like really good
engineering. I think like one thing
which you know we heard also a lot from
like some previous presentations like
small teams can move really fast and
like you kind of need to integrate
research and like engineering systems
engineering aspects to like train a
great LM and I think that's that's
something which they did really well and
yeah sometime sometimes it's harder to
do in bigger settings.
I think there was a combination of a
couple of things. One is that um it was
it was very good open source reasoning
model. We hadn't had one yet. Two, there
was a UX innovation where you could see
the thoughts come out of the model which
you could not do with with 01. And uh
and there were all sorts of just light
bulb moments that the community had by
doing that. And it also just felt more
transparent. So, it jived very well with
with the open-source brand that DeepS's
trying to build. Um, and and
three, they couldn't handle the
inference. So, their their servers were
just completely toast. You couldn't even
pay them. They like blocked the payments
on their on their website. And so,
American companies were forced to figure
out how to scale this up. And like
Fireworks did an incredible job. um
captured most of the inference I think
in the early times as far as our metrics
told us and uh and and we saw not just
like American companies get really
interested but also decentralized
inference providers finally uh have a
model that they could run that people
actually wanted and we saw wild
explosion there that I think most people
in the AI space still aren't aware of.
Dimma, can you give us and not to turn
this into a fireworks advertisement,
which we do not want to do, but give us

uh distinct elements to that model. Um
say say more about anything you can say

Um I mean so first of all like on

uh basically on scaling I mean the model

big like successful open source mixture
of experts models I mean now llama is

because you kind of go into like

there's a lot of interesting engineering

you don't have to turn down customers

mean to your question about kind of

it's like it's really good kind of
pre-training based model and you can

of your previous point about you know
kind of fearongering about that stuff
like in in many I mean in many use cases
it kind of doesn't apply directly right
like you actually want to focus on like
some particular business use case like
this kind of like sensitive elements
which like people post online like they
just don't come up in products in
product questions like if somebody asks

Great. What are your thoughts on llama 4

There is good chance for that and we
